title: Turning 40 made her discover running. Ten years later, she’s running Boston.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Melissa Rousselle, 50 from Haverhill, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for Rebekah’s Angels Foundation.
Rousselle, who began running at 40, uses it as a lifeline for managing depression and anxiety.
The Rebekah's Angels Foundation supports children and families who have experienced trauma with therapy services.

title: For $3 million, a Newton ‘painted lady’ with plenty of whimsy
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: The Charles Davis House at 929 Beacon Street in Newton Center is listed for $2,995,000.
Constructed in 1860, this Painted Lady features six bedrooms, 8.5 bathrooms, and modern upgrades.
The 7,313-square-foot property includes unique gardens, a two-car garage, and views of Crystal Lake.

title: Could Brian Thomas Jr. be a legitimate trade target for Patriots this offseason?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Brian Thomas Jr. recorded 1,200 receiving yards in his rookie season with the Jaguars.
New England Patriots seek dynamic upgrades for quarterback Drake Maye after Super Bowl LX loss to Seattle.
Jaguars may consider trading Brian Thomas Jr. after a drop in production under head coach Liam Coen.

title: 3 takeaways from Team USA men’s hockey’s OT win over Sweden in Olympics
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Quinn Hughes scored in overtime to secure a 2-1 win for Team USA over Sweden at the 2026 Winter Olympics.
Team USA advances to the semifinals to face Slovakia, with puck drop scheduled for 3:10 p.m. EST on Friday.
Four Boston Bruins players, including Charlie McAvoy and Jeremy Swayman, remain in contention for gold in men's hockey.

title: Pittsfield armored vehicle company is largest ICE contract in Mass.
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Lenco Industries in Pittsfield has secured $5.2 million in ICE contracts for its BearCat armored vehicles.
Governor Maura Healey expresses concern about Massachusetts companies contracting with ICE, calls for end to such agreements.
In addition to Lenco, 19 other Massachusetts companies signed contracts with ICE, including BI2 Technologies for biometric systems.

title: Former State Police union head, lobbyist get more prison time for fraud, racketeering
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Dana Pullman and Anne Lynch sentenced for fraud, racketeering, and tax crimes; Pullman gets two years, Lynch 15 months.
Pullman, former Massachusetts State Police union president, ordered to pay $43,915; Lynch, ex-lobbyist, to pay $41,795.
Both exploited union positions for personal gain, including kickbacks and misuse of union funds, according to prosecutors.

title: Boston 25 News head meteorologist Kevin Lemanowicz departing after 3 decades with the station
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Kevin Lemanowicz, chief meteorologist, to leave Boston 25 News on February 27 after nearly 30 years.
Lemanowicz joined Boston 25 News at its inception in 1996, covering major weather events in New England.
Boston 25 News praised Lemanowicz for his accurate forecasts and connection with viewers, emphasizing his service to the community.

title: Red Sox release statement after outcry over flawed jersey design
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Red Sox responded to fan complaints about design flaws in their 2026 home jerseys.
The team acknowledged the issue with overlapping lettering and will redesign the jerseys for Opening Day.
The Red Sox confirmed Fanatics followed their specifications and praised them for quick adjustments.

title: Pawtucket police find firearms in ice rink shooter’s storage locker, identify ‘courageous citizens’ who intervened
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Police found a sawed-off shotgun, AR-15 style rifle, and ammunition in the suspect's Maine storage locker.
Robert Dorgan killed his ex-wife and son during a family dispute at a Pawtucket hockey game.
Courageous citizens subdued the shooter and provided critical first aid, preventing further injuries.

title: MBTA announces service changes and suspensions for March
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: The MBTA will suspend Orange Line and four Commuter Rail lines for signal and modernization upgrades during weekends in March.
Orange Line service will be suspended between Back Bay and Forest Hills from Feb. 28 to March 8; shuttle buses provided.
Commuter Rail suspensions affect Fitchburg, Haverhill, Lowell, and Newburyport/Rockport lines starting Feb. 21; shuttle buses available.
